issues.description: The problem statement (Part 2, description of the controller API) incorrectly states that each method takes a Consumer<List<Note>> parameter while the exercise and template expect Consumer<List<Person>> for the PersonController methods. This typo can confuse students about the expected generic type for the callback parameter when implementing PersonController.get/add/update/delete methods.
issues.suggested_fix: Fix the problem statement text to reference Consumer<List<Person>> when describing the PersonController methods (Part 2). This aligns the textual description with the method signatures in the template and the solution and avoids confusion for students.

issues.description: The template's PersonService declares the stored collection as a List<Person> and includes an explicit note 'do not change this'. The solution repository, however, changes that attribute to a Set<Person> (and changes the constructor accordingly). This is a structural mismatch between template and solution and violates the problem note, which may confuse students or graders and can lead to test/compatibility issues.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the solution with the template and the problem instruction: revert the PersonService storage attribute in the solution to the same type used in the template (List<Person>) and adjust the sorting implementation to operate on a List. Alternatively, if Set<Person> is intended, update the template, the 'do not change this' note, and the problem statement to explicitly require a Set and explain why. Keeping the attribute type consistent across template, problem statement, and solution will avoid confusion and test failures.
